channel.title: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: NASA’s Lunar Flashlight Ready to Search for the Moon’s Water Ice
item.description: Set for a November launch, the small satellite mission will use lasers to search for water ice inside the darkest craters at the Moon’s South Pole.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: Equipping LOFTID’s Sensors for a Fiery Descent Back to Earth
item.description: NASA’s Low-Earth Orbit Flight Test of an Inflatable Decelerator mission will test a new heat shield designed to inflate to protect heavier payloads on the journey through an atmosphere.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: Smooth Rides Ahead for Advanced Air Mobility Aircraft
item.description: Airline passengers today expect a smooth ride with little turbulence. While turbulence can’t always be avoided, aircraft design considerations and designs limit what the passenger feels.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: NASA Inflatable Heat Shield Finds Strength in Flexibility
item.description: NASA Inflatable Heat Shield Finds Strength in Flexibility
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: NASA in Silicon Valley Lands at AIAA Ascend 2022
item.description: This week, experts, students, entrepreneurs, and enthusiasts from across the space exploration community will meet online and in Las Vegas, NV for the AIAA Ascend Conference.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: What are Ames’ Contributions to LOFTID?
item.description: NASA’s Low-Earth Orbit Flight Test of an Inflatable Decelerator (LOFTID) mission tests a new inflatable heat shield that could enable large-scale missions to Mars, Venus, and Titan, as well as re-entering Earth's atmosphere.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: NASA to Recover Lots of Data from Tiny Package During Tech Demo
item.description: NASA to Recover Lots of Data from Tiny Package During Tech Demo
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: Congresswoman Eshoo Tours SOFIA Flying Observatory Upon Its Retirement
item.description: On Oct. 14, 2022, Rep. Anna G. Eshoo and Eugene Tu, center director at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California’s Silicon Valley, visited the now-retired Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: NASA’s S-MODE Field Campaign Deploys to the Pacific Ocean
item.description: The mission’s fleet of ship, aircraft, and marine robotics will study ocean eddies and other elusive features near the surface that have a big influence on climate.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features

item.title: Collision May Have Formed the Moon in Mere Hours, Simulations Reveal
item.description: Most theories claim the Moon formed out of the debris of this collision, coalescing in orbit over months or years. A new simulation puts forth a different theory – the Moon may have formed immediately, in a matter of hours, when material from the Earth and Theia were launched directly into orbit after the impact.
item.source: NASA Ames Research Center - News and Features
